. I'm currently pondering on the registration, so here is my request for comments:
1) Use the applications management url as the unique identifier. Therefore, it is possible to register two applications with the same name but with distinctive urls. (Impacts UI, no need to do the Application.query() anymore)
2) Option to specify the clientUrl via property (spring.boot.admin.client.url). This defaults to http://hostname:management.port/management.context-path (see gh-17).
3) Using spring.application.name as application name, defaulting to 'spring-boot-application' (so it becomes optional).
4) Make the registration less chatty (no GET before POST).
I also thought about an option to pass along arbitrary, customizable key-value-properties on registration? Model would look like:
- Application
  - url:String
  - name:String
  - properties:Map

. Since passing around URLs in URLs causes problems on all ends (Tomcat, AngularJS), an Id (to pass around and as storage-key) is already derived from the URL. It should be no problem to alter the computation producing shortened SHA1-Hashes (like in git). I like the Idea.
. Imho it would be good to seperate the three different modules/topics into three seperate PRs.
On the caching:
1) I miss the part where the ApplicationRegistry is connected to the cache or am I just blind?
2) I agree that it should be possible to plug in a (distributed) cache. But specifying the implementation (hazelcast) is to opinionated. What if i want to use ehcache?
So in my opinion we should support caching (through Spring Cache Abstraction). And only provide an example for using hazelcast.
On Security:
1) In my opinion the same applies here. We should provide a simple example on how to configure security. It seems to me that it is a lot code for security configuration. Maybe we should have a look at spring boot actuators ManagementSecurityAutoConfiguration as blueprint. 
2) Is the security supported on the UI?
3) Securing the management API is out of scope for spring boot admin, since it belongs to the spring boot actuator. Spring boot acutator already supports securing the management API, so in my opinion your ManagementSecurityConfig is redundant.
On the Code

Currently the CORS-Filter is active for all requests. 
We have to work on this, the filter should only be active for management-endpoints.
. Imho we shouldn't do that, it leads to a false sense of security.
When the management-endpoints are routed via the server we are serving foreign (perhaps harmful) to the browser. So Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) would be circumvented totally. 
So instead we should employ CORS and ship appropriate http-headers, making transparent where the resources are loaded from.

. Ok, I did take a look on using https with spring boot admin.
- If a client want's to register at a https-secured admin-server, the client must trust the admin-servers certificate.
- If a client has registered with a https-secured management url the admin-server must trust the clients certificate. This is because the requests from the UI will be forwarded by the admin-server to the client and therefore the admin-server must trust the clients certificate.
For me, after importing the clients certificate into a keystore and using it via javax.net.ssl.trustStore and javax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword-system properties everything works nicely.
p.s. I think I don't have to clarify that the registered managment url must be reachable from the admin server....
. The autodetection of https on client is a good idea.

The UI is a bunch of static files in spring-boot-admin-server-ui.jar/META-INF/resources (compliant as of servlet 3.0 spec). So if you want to serve the files from elsewhere you need to customize the way spring mvc is servering these resources.

. I wonder if it is really reasonable putting all the three into one single app. Every one has it's own responsibility (service discovery, configuration, monitoring) in terms of microservices you really should keep 'em separated.
This is not a quite easy task (while loosing some of the boot magic), since not only the static resources has to be served under a different context path, but also the REST-api. 
Making the Controller & ResourceHandler configurable or registering a separate Servlet will unnecessarily bloat our code.

. Are you using the spring-boot-parent for your war-file or the spring-boot-dependencies import? 
If yes, it won't help adding the dependency once more in spring-boot-admin-starter-client/pom.xml because the dependencyManagement of your pom.xml  (from boot-parent or boot-dependency import) will mark it as optional - and therefore json-simple won't be included in your war using the maven war-packaging. 
As a workaround you can use the spring-boot-maven-plugin and build a fat-war. The boot-packager will include json-simple into the war. Or just define the dependency yourself...

My 5 cents:
If you hand over the credentials to the admin server, so that you can access the endpoints via the zuul proxy at /api/applications/{id}/* without credentials, so you don't have achieved any additional security.
You could then secure the admin server with the result, that one password gives you access to all your applications. So in turn you could also use the same credentials for all your applications.
And in case your are not using https for the admin <-> application communication the passwords would be transmitted in plaintext...
Just an additional note:
The health-endpoint is currently required to report the status (details not needed) without credentials. For achieving this see Spring Boot Reference - HTTP health endpoint access restrictions
. spring.boot.admin.username spring.boot.admin.password are the credentials used for the post-request to register the application - so has to be set on client side. If you get a 403, you got a wrong password/user.
If you only include a spring-security and have no security.user.password set in the admin server a random one is generated. See Spring Boot Reference Guide - Security

. So I found (imho) a good solution: First of all I've added the auto-registration property.
Second there is an easy solution regarding the desired endpoint:
If you are using spring-cloud-context and leverage the extended environment-endpoint you can add this piece of code to your @Configuration:
``` java
    @Autowired
    private RegistrationApplicationListener listener;
@Autowired
private Environment env;

@EventListener
public void onContextRefresh(EnvironmentChangeEvent event) {
    Boolean runRegistration = env.getProperty("runRegistration", Boolean.class, true);
    LOGGER.info("Environment changed! runRegistration = {}", runRegistration);
    if (runRegistration) {
        listener.startRegisterTask();
    } else {
        listener.stopRegisterTask();
    }
}

```
Now when you do a POST request to /env?runRegistration=false the registration task will be stopped...

. > I am trying to centralize Eureka, Zuul, Config Server, SpringBoot Admin Server etc.. in a single component.
I don't think this is a good idea. It's totally opposed to the microservice idea....
EurekaServer is for ServiceRegistry/Discovery
AdminServer is for Monitoring
ZuulProxy is a proxy-server / api-gateway / edge-service
Three totally unrelated concerns which you should handle separate.
... and since the admin server itself contains a zuul proxy this doesn't mix very well.
So adding the EurekaServer should work but not adding the zuul.
. > I would like to disagree here. ZuulProxy is a functionality that can be used in different ways. One is the "API Gateway / Edge Service" way how Netflix is using Zuul. 
You are right. But a ZuulProxy which is needed to drive your business must not be included in your monitoring or dashboard applications. And currently  adding a 2nd zuul to the admin server won't work (unless you are doing a ApplicationContext-hierarchy, which I think will be more error-prone and tedious than setting up a second service)

... but adding several admin related features in one service is a valid approach in my opinion.

For your business applications you are doing microservices and for your admin tools you are building a monolith? Come on!
If you entangle all these things you can't release/update/deploy them separate. If you just put it all together in one service for the sake of a single adress, put a reverse proxy / edge service in front.
But as always it is a trade-off depending on your context.

We are not running on a PaaS platform yet and creating a new microservice involves some initial setup effort and continuous maintenance effort from operations.

Three words: cattle not pets
Doing microservices puts you in the need for automation.

. The ui queries the /configprops endpoint to look whether the /logfile endpoint is enabled.
The /logfile-endpoint is only enabled when your client hast the logging.file property set. So in case you are using boot's launch.script or some other init.d script, which just redirects the output, the /logfile endpoint is disabled.

. Ok. The logfile endpoint is mvc only, so the bean (and the associated configprops) is only created in the managment application context. 
So the detection of the endpoint in the ui needs a fix.
The best to do here is a HEAD request to the logfile endpoint.

. You should implement your own ServiceInstanceConverter for Consul and add it to your admin server configuration. 
If it's working well, a PR is appreciated. I didn't take a look for discovery with Consul, yet.
. Just include the bean in your Configuration class, e.g.:
java
@SpringBootApplication
@Configuration
@EnableAdminServer
@EnableDiscoveryClient
public class AdminDemoApplication {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SpringApplication.run(AdminDemoApplication.class, args);
    }
   @Bean
   public ConsulServiceInstanceConverter() {
      return new ConsulServiceInstanceConverter();
   }
}
FYI:
Using @SpringBootApplication and @EnableAutoConfiguration is redundant since the former includes the latter.

. I would suggest you to include these informations in your info-endpoint. Which is already shown in spring boot admin.
. > ... they present unnecessary burden on every application developer having to explicitly include them in the configuration.
I'd suggest one of the following ways around this:
1) you add these information during your (standardised?) build process (for example with maven filtering) - I guess the information is available in your pom.xml or build environment.
2) you write a custom InfoEndpoint which contains the information
3) you implement a InfoContributor (spring boot 1.4.x) adding the information

Can you elaborate as to why you are reluctant to consider this feature, or at least to discuss it?

1) You could already show the desired information right now without any change to SBA
2) I don't think its a heavy burden to add the informations to the /info endpoint. If you don't want to do it manually for every app over and over again - automate it! (solutions given above)
3) Imho the info endpoint is the right place where your application should show additional information.
4) SBA uses  the info endpoint to show additional infos for you app. If you would only submit them to SBA the information is not available to others.
5) SBA doesn't need any metadata to do it's work and therefore doesn't accept such. Your proposal needs extensions of the rest api.

Would you be willing to accept a PR if I submit one for this functionality?

I would accept a PR that would enhance the info section and render things that looks like urls as links.

. When using your UTF-8 characters in application.yml everything is correct. 
Using your characters in an application.properties on the other hand, the name is displayed incorrect. This is due to spring boot loading .properties-files with ISO-8859-1 as default charset (for more read here: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/5361).
If there is no way around you for the .properties-file you need to use the unicode-escapes and ISO-8859-1 as charset. The escapes would be \u6d4b\u8bd5 in your case.

btw, the client registers as "DOWN" not as "OFFLINE" - a slight difference OFFLINE = no tcp connect - DOWN = not HTTP-OK (200)

When using Eureka the SBA server can only use the information published by the Eureka registry: the healthCheckUrlPath and the service url (doesn't contain the servlet.context-path!) - so these need to be correct (and you need to set the healthCheckUrlPath explicitly when using non default context-path, see http://cloud.spring.io/spring-cloud-netflix/spring-cloud-netflix.html#_status_page_and_health_indicator).
In this case SBA server can't guess anything based on the server.context-path or management.context-path, since it simply doesn't know about the values for the registered application.
This would only apply if you are using the SBA client - then the client computes the correct urls and uses them to register at the server...). What would you expect?
. With default docker config, the problem is that the container running the admin server cannot resolve the hostname of the client.
In this case you can set spring.boot.admin.client.prefer-ip=true on the client, so the  client uses it's ip address to register at the admin, which should be reachable (if running on the same network).
Another way around this would need a DNS so that the admin container can resolve the hostname.

The default value is 10000ms. The point is not a decimal point but a thousand sepearator. Sorry for the misunderstanding. I'll fix the docs on this.
The check is done every 10000ms (period) and each application is checked at most every 10000ms (status-lifetime). This means in the worst case the refresh is made after 19999ms.

You need to build a notifier chain like that: RemindingNotifier --> FilteringNotifier --> MailNotifier.
The RemindingNotifier will resend notifications as long as the application is not up again. The FilteringNotifierwill throw them away while the filter is active. A filter can be set via the REST-api - which you need to do before the deployment and either you let the filter expire automatically or you need remove the filter after the deployment. If the application is back up before the filter expires you get no notification, but if the application doesn't come back online you will recieve notifications repeatedly until the application is back up again.. it is..

java
    @Bean
    public InstanceExchangeFilterFunction auditLog() {
        return (instance, request, next) -> {
            if (HttpMethod.DELETE.equals(request.method()) || HttpMethod.POST.equals(request.method())) {
                log.info("{} for {} on {}", request.method(), instance.getId(), request.url());
            }
            return next.exchange(request);
        };
    }

The MemoryUsage Mbean doesn't tell if it is unbounded or not.
From the Java doc:

max | represents the maximum amount of memory (in bytes) that can be used for memory management. Its value may be undefined. The maximum amount of memory may change over time if defined. The amount of used and committed memory will always be less than or equal to max if max is defined. A memory allocation may fail if it attempts to increase the used memory such that used > committed even if used <= max would still be true (for example, when the system is low on virtual memory).

Unfortunately there is no info available if the maximum is unbounded or not. So we can't decide on that.

@Bean
    public MappingJackson2HttpMessageConverter actuatorHttpMessageConverter() {

            Jackson2ObjectMapperBuilder.json().featuresToDisable(WRITE_DATES_AS_TIMESTAMPS).build());
        converter.setSupportedMediaTypes(
            Collections.singletonList(MediaType.parseMediaType(ActuatorMediaType.V2_JSON)));
        return converter;
    }

The placeholders are resolved by Spring at startup time and when a placeholder can't be resolved it will be left as is. In your case the url the UriComponentsBuilder (inside SBA server!)  recieves the property with the unresolved placeholder (from your eureka client!) and tries to resolve it again but lacks the needed context for this.
The property must not contain any unresolved placeholders. When the management.port is unset the best thing to do, is to default the value like this: ${management.port:${server.port:8080}}. In case you want to prevent any unresolved placeholders at startup, do it like this: 
``
    @Bean
    public static PropertySourcesPlaceholderConfigurer propertySourcesPlaceholderConfigurer() {
        PropertySourcesPlaceholderConfigurer propertySourcesPlaceholderConfigurer = new PropertySourcesPlaceholderConfigurer();
        propertySourcesPlaceholderConfigurer.setIgnoreUnresolvablePlaceholders(true);
        return propertySourcesPlaceholderConfigurer;
    }

. Wow, a lot of great ideas :-) Thank you for this! Here are my short opinions about the points:
1) Service Registration - We are using SBA to monitor the health of the applications. When an application shuts down gracefully and doesn't come up - maybe after redeployment - then we want to see it in SBA. So it would be great when you make this feature configurable over a flag. Maybe a manual deregistration option in the GUI would also be cool.
2) Security -  The idea with @ EnableAdminServerSecurity sounds great :-)
3) Service Discovery - I'm also very ambivalent at this point. There are a some great products outside (e.g. Eureka). I experimented with the registration implementation from Eureka, but I decided to replace it not with the simple existing solution. Mh, I think we should discuss if we would like to use SBA as a service discovery solution.
Please create feature branches for each of this points, so it's easier for us to get a detailed overview :-)
. +1 for EnableAdminServerSwagger

. Hi thx for your answer.
1) I agree that applications shouldn't be removed automatically, if they are down. But in the case I shut down an application gracefully, it should unregister itself automatically. 
I've also added an unregister method to the controller and I would like to add the functionality to the SpringBootAdminClientAutoConfiguration that the application unregisters itself if the Spring context is shutdown gracefully.
One more enhancement idea: I would like to add a 
@ConditionalOnProperty("spring.boot.admin.enabled") to the client auto configuration.
2) I've added a spring-boot-admin-security maven-module which activates security, when you add the library and an EnableAdminServerSecurity annotation to your Application configuration. The type of security is BasicAuth and optinally a custom Security-mechanism, which could be project-specific. You can configure the optional Security-mechanism via Beans.
I can push it to my repository if you would like to have a look at it. 
Sensitive Actuator endpoints (like env, trace or metrics) of the client application might also be secured, or the management contextpath could be customized. 
Is there already an option in the Web Ui to customize the actuator endpoint URLs and security (e.g. BasicAuth)? 
I would suggest that the client application has to send detailed information about its Actuator endpoints during the registration phase (e.g. customized URLs, if an endpoint is secured and the security mechanism used). In that way a project is able to customize the contextpath and/or endpoints names. 
3) Spring Cloud Eureka and Hashicorps Consul also have Admin Uis included. Personally, I think that Service information and metrics also belong to a service discovery server. 
In that way I could be able to select a service of a specific version, hostname/ip or datacenter. Either in the Admin Ui or via the Rest API. I think many features overlap.

. Hello,
I think the applications management url could be used as the unique identifier, but it should be the hash code of the url or the apllication object.
If you want to search for a registered application, you don't want to enter the whole management url as the search ID. 
e.g. http://localhost:8080/api/apllication/{http://localhost:8080/api/apllication/management}
In my solution, with Hazelcast as the storage provider, I create a cluster-wide unique ID for each registered application. 
. Changes:
- Hazelcast is the storage provider of the Registry Map. You are able to start many spring-boot-admin instances and they build a distributed cache cluster. Hazelcast can be configured via the application.yaml config file.
- The Registry API is more "Restful". RegisterApplication returns HTTP Code 201 "Created" and a location field now. UnregisterApplication and UnregisterAllApplications returns HTTP Code 204 "No Content". The API is documented via Swagger.
- The Application domain model is immutable and can be build via the Builder pattern.
- The spring-boot-admin-server module contains many new Integration Tests.
- Correct Spring REST exception handling was added. All Spring exceptions are translated to the correct HTTP Codes now. A new "ApplicationNotFound" exception was introduced.
. Hello Johannes,
thanks for your comments.
On the caching: 
- Hazelcast cache is connected now.
- At the moment it is not possible to switch the cache provider. I started to implement it with JCache Annotations, but I loose Hazelcast configuration options then.
On Security:
- There is a lot of code, because it allows to customize Spring Security and allows us to add other Authentication mechanism than BasicAuth easily. I didn't have time to document/comment it yet. 
- The Code allows to use different Autentication mechanism and roles for the Registry API, Admin UI, Admin Actuator Endpoints and Swagger UI. For example i want to have Swagger UI not secured, but Admin UI accessible only for Admins and Registry API only for Client Applications and Admin UI.
- The Admin Web UI is not updated yet. That's why Security is not enabled yet.
- The Spring Boot Security AutoConfiguration can not handle that as flexible as this code can. 
  I have researched the Spring Boot SecurityAutoConfiguration a lot.
On the code:
- Package issue was fixed
- AdminServerAuthenticationEntryPoint and AdminServerWebAuthenticationDetails
  and AdminServerAuthenticationToken are there for customization. If you need a more complex authentcation mechanism, you have to customize them. I did not delete the code, because I think it is valuable to know how to customize them.

- Currently the RegistryController and SimpleApplicationRegistry are not ThreadSafe. This is a sort of breaking change, unfortunately. I could not come up with a better way to do it. I had to switch to using the application name as the key for the registry instead of the ID, which was being set as the artifact id. This is in order to differentiate between instances of the same app. Additionally, I put the URL to the client app on the main page, which does make it a bit crowded and not always display the best... but I am not very good at UI. I am certainly open to suggestions on how to improve this... Perhaps make the application name a clickable link to the URL instead? It could also display the URL when hovering over the name.

. > When there are many environments where the Spring Boot Admin server will be deployed to, it would be helpful to see the environment name as part of the UI.
This seems like a great idea, given that Spring Boot Admin makes it easier to use actuator endpoints that can affect the behavior of applications. It is important to make users aware of which environment they are interacting, and just having different URLs is often overlooked.
Changing the background color is another way to help distinguish between environments.. We're also interested in this support and are willing to help. As far as I understand, without this support, there is no way for the instance status in SBA to be accurate in a Cloud Foundry environment since it isn't necessarily being routed to the instance it thinks it is (unless there's only one instance, of course).. @joshiste 

Please write a dedicated CloudFoundryInstanceIdGenerator and a dedicated CloudFoundryHttpHeaderProvider without modyfing the existing implementations.
The CloudFoundry-* implementations should be instantiated via AutoConfiguration detecting that the server is running on cloudfoundry.

I initially thought the same thing, but the need for these Cloud Foundry-aware variants is actually dependent on the Spring Boot Admin client's platform, not the server's platform. In many organizations, this could be expected (assumed?) to always be the same, but not in all. Alternatively, all clients may not be running on Cloud Foundry - this is actually true of my organization's current situation. Furthermore, these variants (as they are implemented now) do not negatively affect the behavior of clients that are not on Cloud Foundry, since those clients won't send the Cloud Foundry-specific metadata. Though, of course, I agree this should be demonstrated in tests.
Would you still prefer separate classes given the above?. You can add those values to the environment in an EnvironmentPostProcessor that is conditionally registered when CloudFoundry is detected.. @joshiste 

may be this needs the concept for a MetadataContributor in the client project...

It does seem a MetadataContributor concept would be helpful for the client-side implementation. Using an EnvironmentPostProcessor or just injecting and mutating the metadata in a @Configuration class feels like more of a workaround.. @joshiste in your testing, did you see how much native memory was used?
In briefly searching about the issue, I came across this blog which advises configuring Netty's leak detection. This guide from Oracle might also prove helpful in investigating this issue.. Please try with the latest release version of Spring Boot. Currently that is 2.0.1.RELEASE. The RC1 version you are using won't be compatible with the latest snapshots of Spring Boot Admin.. @joshiste I debugged this some, and the root context is the Spring Cloud bootstrap context. For reasons I still don't understand, it doesn't get the ClosedContextEvent, which I can reproduce in an application with only the spring-cloud-starter dependency and an @EventListener for ContextClosedEvent. It is only called for the main application's ClosedContextEvent. So I don't think the auto-deregistration when on a cloud platform feature is working for any applications using Spring Cloud.. We explored this internally a bit, and the only way we could come up with to get the latest route information for a running app programmatically is to call the Cloud Foundry Cloud Controller with the cf-java-client, for example. In addition to the added dependency, this would require extra configuration for credentials. It all seemed too much, and we changed our process so that apps are restarted if routes are changed. It isn't ideal, but I'm not sure the alternative is better (calling the controller for the current routes every registration request, from every instance). scheduled tasks. This property source name seems a little misleading. Something that indicates the property source is added for spring Boot Admin clients on cloud foundry would be better, in my opinion.. It might be a good idea to make this conditional on the user not having specified the property. Personally, I don't think it makes sense to disable auto-deregistration on cloud foundry, but a user should nonetheless have the ability to do so easily if desired.. Will this cause an exception on startup if there is no route mapped to the application? Perhaps checking for that should be worked into the condition since it doesn't make sense to register with spring Boot Admin without an accessible http route, I think.. I know this name was chosen to match the DiscoveryClient, but I find it a little unfortunate. There is such a thing as the instance ID, which is a GUID like the application ID. This property is really the instance index, as it is named in the VCAP application properties.. It's a tough call, I think. It depends on users' environment/platform and practices. If always deploying the same instances to the same machines, it might be nice to see an instance is down (stopped) in between deploys/restarts. Perhaps opening a separate issue and gathering feedback would be a good idea.. Does this need to be done in a custom InstanceProperties class? It seems like this logic could be done in the EnvironmentPostProcessor, which would maybe be a bit more intuitive since the only purpose of extending InstanceProperties here seems to be to conditionally set serviceBaseUrl; not to add any additional properties as one might expect from extending.. I know that the CloudFoundryVcapEnvironmentPostProcessor adds the property with this name, but we should probably follow the Relaxed Binding 2.0 advice and use the uniform format here and anywhere else. That is, kebab-case: vcap.application.application-id. I also wonder if it would be better practice to make something like a VcapApplicationProperties class that is annotated with @ConfigurationProperties("vcap.application") and the fields we want. Then pass that in the constructor to this class, rather than using @Value annotations to inject individual properties. That would also make testing this class easier.. Doesn't this bean need to be marked @Primary because there is more than one InstanceIdGenerator bean?. This appears to not be used..

Yes, you are right - all endpoints are reachable from private network only. If we add basic auth via https it should be enough to meet company security policy. 
On the other hand, integration with oauth2 flow in addition/instead to basic auth would be great also.
. Just one more thing, to get this authorization prototype to work filter
https://github.com/codecentric/spring-boot-admin/blob/master/spring-boot-starter-admin-client/src/main/java/de/codecentric/boot/admin/web/EndpointCorsFilter.java
should also accept authorization header.
. That's true. but Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true header is missing.
http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/cors/#toc-adding-cors-support-to-the-server
Nevertheless we made it works, without application modifications. Admin application is secured by basic auth, and all clients have the same credentials. On admin app node we have apache proxy, with rules per client app. Finally, when we authenticate in admin app browser does the rest without cors problems, because all clients endpoints are available under http://admin.app.com/client_url.com/actuator. Not the best solution, because for each client app we need to create new rule in proxy settings, but works ;)
. I like this idea. I'm using something very alike with custom eureka based ApplicationStore, and everything works like a charm, including basic auth. 
Plus, using proxy allows to secure actuator endpoints just by setting listening address to 127.0.0.1 and only set up security in admin application, if everything is working on one server.
.

. Hello @dgomesbr,
let's try to keep things simple and don't mix up stuff here. 
The changes to .gitignore are unrelated to the issue (which is about adding coveralls support). We should leave this change out and create a separate issue for it. My personal opinion about this is, to add nothing to .gitignore that is specific to a dev environment (for example .settings). This stuff belongs in your global gitignore file. The only thing that should be in .gitignore are temp files generated by your build tools, like the target folder generated by maven or sample files for the build like build.properties.sample.
I would also like to see a separate PR for the house keeping in pom.xml.
Splitting things up makes it easier to review stuff and creates a clearer git history.
May I ask you to modify your PR?
best regards,
Benedikt

jar349:
I wouldn't want to register '/' because it would transmit the whole app.  But in my static assets, I can create a /health.html page that returns a 200 or a /#/health Angular route that returns a 204.  This will be fast, and will show that my static assets are being served.
If I integrated a health indicator in my REST service, I don't know how I'd show the health information in spring-boot-admin.  Additionally, my REST service would become coupled to the web app.

https://github.com/codecentric/spring-boot-admin/issues/145.
. We solved the security problem by using SSL mutual authentication on the
Admin Server application and passing the user credentials to the monitored
applications via headers in a ZuulFilter. The applications run behind a
firewall and are only accessible through a reverse proxy (nginx) and from
the Admin Server. This works well in a private organization where you can
generate your certificates using a private CA.

I am sure that this could be solved somehow with OAuth2 as well however I
don't have experience working with it. Our applications are behind a
corporate firewall so we don't use OAuth2 providers and don't have our own
resource/token server at this time.
I could certainly write something in the docs about "Securing Using SSL
Mutual Authentication" and document what I've done if you are interested in
implementation details.
-Steve

. For authentication, a login page that matches the look and feel of the rest
of the UI would be nice, but authentication to the web application itself
should be up to the user. I may want to implement Basic Auth, LDAP
authentication, SSL mutual authentication, OAuth, leave that up to me.

The bigger issue right now is handling the authentication to the
applications the Spring Boot Admin application is monitoring. Currently
only basic auth (or nothing is supported) and this requires every client
application to have the same username/password. This is not ideal. To me a
better solution is to proxy the user credentials to the applications being
monitored (not required to simply check the health but for each of the
other pages) and have each of those applications decide if the user is able
to access the specific endpoints.
- Steve
. @joshiste @mirwais27 If I recall correctly, the DefaultServiceInstanceConverter is created and marked with @ConditionalOnMissingBean but this would be conditional on a missing bean of type DefaultServiceInstanceConverter. The method signature should probably return ServiceInstanceConverter so that any bean of type ServiceInstanceConverter would override the default one. A work-around to that would be to have ConsulServiceInstanceConverter extend DefaultServiceInstanceConverter which should then cause the bean in the auto-configuration to not be created.

example.

mrumpf:
OK, I understand. We separated the Admin UI & the Hystrix Dashboard from the Eureka and Config server now.
p.s. You can set the server.contextPath, but that moves all applications to a new context path.
. There is a section in the Hystrix Wiki about embedding the dashboard functionaility into another dashboard:
https://github.com/Netflix/Hystrix/wiki/Dashboard#customizing-and-embedding
. I would like to disagree here. ZuulProxy is a functionality that can be used in different ways.
One is the "API Gateway / Edge Service" way how Netflix is using Zuul. The other one is to do some simple proxying to admin functionality for example that is used by a small group of admins only.
We have an admin microservice which does several things:
1. Host the codecentric spring-boot-admin 
2. Host the Hystrix Dashboard
3. Host the Netflix Vector UI
4. Use the admin microservice as a (Zuul) proxy to different admin features of other microservices (single entry point; api gateway) for a very limited scope of admin functionality
I agree with you that the non-related features "Eureka", "Spring Cloud Config", and "Spring Boot Admin" should not be put into one microservice, but adding several admin related features in one service is a valid approach in my opinion. We are not running on a PaaS platform yet and creating a new microservice involves some initial setup effort and continuous maintenance effort from operations. Adding a new microservice in such a corner case is not a reasonable option.
. :) I also prefer living in a simple world. Unfortunately reality is more complex. The corporate environment I live in changes very slowly. Yes, we are automating a lot of stuff, providing new VMs for an application is not part of it because our IT provider still lives in the "old" world and I cannot change that. Besides that the customer has chosen to use static infrastructure instead of a dynamic cloud environment. These are the reasons why we are forced not to move every little aspect into a separate microservice because the maintenance bill would explode.
But anyway, thanks for your time.
. There must be a choice on whether an action should be executed on one or on multiple nodes.
When debugging a high traffic application it is probably wise to enable DEBUG level for one logger only for one node out of many nodes.
But when a service's log is too noisy, it would be cool to set the log to a silent level on all nodes at once. Especially if you have more than 2 nodes.. We are approaching 150 microservices in our system soon. With the Spring Boot Admin server a user can easily change the configuration or the log level of any microservice in the system, although the user should only be able to do that for a small fraction of the 150 microservices. 
I know that SBA uses the Actuator endpoints of Spring Boot and adding an audit feature would not prevent someone from doing a curl against the Actuator endpoints directly, but having a central place in SBA where all write operations are logged would be very convenient to check what was modified. The following operations are of interest:
 Override config values
 Change log levels
* Create thread dumps
The issue I see is that SBA does not have the concept of a user. But we run SBA behind a SSO solution so that we have a HTTP header parameter which contains the user identity.. The centralization and the content of the audit logging is the idea here.
The Actuator audit logging provides "login auditing" events only (per default):
https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/reference/html/production-ready-auditing.html
We use an ELK stack for making all our log files searchable.
I see 2 possible solutions:
1. Add an auditing feature to SBA
  * Con: This is not bullet proof because one could use curl to do modifications
  * Pro: No additional software necessary to get an overview on all config events
2. Extend the auditing feature of Spring Actuator so that config changes, log level changes and thread dumps are written to the audit log.
  * Con: This solution has the drawback that you need e.g. an ELK stack to collect all logs from all instances.
  * Pro: It covers all invocations to the Spring Actuator endpoints, even the ones that do not get triggered by SBA 
So in our case, because we already have ELK in place, solution 2 would be fine. For those not having this in place, solution 1 would be preferrable.. Thanks for the hint. We will give that a try..

Sorry
. That's why I've upgraded to Brixton.M3, not to the latest M5 which introduced major non backward compatible API changes.
. > So did I get it right, that the response from the spring boot admin server contains the class-field and the ApplicationRegistrator can't read it?
It's actually the opposite, the rest template sends Application without @class attribute, but argument resolver uses mapper with enabled default typing and fails.
I've managed to force rest template to use object mapper with enableDefaultTyping, but then javascript code fails to parse json with @class attributes.
I'll try to deploy boot admin within it's own context (dispatcherServlet).
.

staleks:
Ok, to put more info in investigation of this issue.
I've checked more logs and found that on Spring Cloud Config Server (another component of my system), I was receiving 404. 
I checked the reason for this, and found out that I had this in application.yml of Spring Cloud Config Server
management:
     context-path: /admin
As a side effect, spring cloud config wasn't be able to find
localhost:8888/health, but rather it was moved to localhost:8888/admin/health
Once I get this to default one, Spring Boot Admin was able to start.
Now I can get admin-ui but I can see just 3 services:
- config server (port: 8888)
- itself, spring boot admin (port: 8585) and
- zuul (port: 8765)
I have other services, 2, 3 more microService that I can see from eureka side, but those are not visible from Spring Boot Admin app.
. Hi,
you just made your point :)
You are 100% right, so this part is producing exception:
public void discover() {
        for (String serviceId : discoveryClient.getServices()) {
            for (ServiceInstance instance : discoveryClient.getInstances(serviceId)) {
                registry.register(convert(instance));
            }
        }
    }
So I have Eureka UP, and Cloud-Config UP and my first microService UP.
Starting Spring Boot Admin, in a debug mode, I've put break-point in for and I see that
discoveryClient.getServices() has two elements. That was expected, I guess :) Eureka anyway shouldn't be in this list.
So elements are:
- my microService and
- cloud config server.
Method registry.register(convert(instance)); pass OK for my microService, while 2nd service, 
cloud config server, fails on that method registry.register(convert(instance));.
Error is same as I've already posted, so I don't want to repeat myself.
java.lang.ClassCastException: java.lang.Integer cannot be cast to java.lang.String
. My spot light goes to this:
Please note that there is convert(instance).
I've debbuged a bit more:
String healthUrl = append(managementUrl, healthEndpoint);
When I execute this: I've got
2015-11-07 21:28:32.895 DEBUG 10116 --- [  restartedMain] o.s.web.client.RestTemplate              : GET request for "http://192.168.1.103:8888/health" resulted in 404 (Not Found)
which is clearly not ok, since it has mngmt part /admin before /health.
. Actually, your previous suggestion fixed that stuff.
. I've just downloaded it and start all 4:
- eureka

- my microService and

Everything is fine so far.
Related to your last post, I am even wondering if I will need config server to have /admin, but
that was some example that I've used in process of evaluation.

Release comming soon ?

There seems to be a Bug in actuator 1.3.0 when using a different management port! I always used another one for our own apps due to security reasons (management port is only accessible locally).
server.port=8085

See this commit for how I changed things up to make everything work:
https://github.com/fastnsilver/grivet/commit/63dfbdf515f012839cdb65872b062be1bf2c0cfc

Anyhow, I'm good with the discovery approach rather than with having to add spring-boot-admin-client dependency to all client POMs.  And as for not being able to look at logs, well, in my setup, I pump logs to logstash so I can see them there.

//@see https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-2.0.0-M1-Release-Notes#actuator-default-mapping

ntatsumi:
For basic HTTP authentication, the Zuul tweak you need is zuul.sensitive-headers=Cookie,Set-Cookie property. Zuul has the property set to 'Authorization,Cookie,Set-Cookie' by default. You need to prevent Zuul from stripping out the Authorization header.

ptahchiev:
Hello,
let me join in this discussion by sharing my thoughts. 
- Indeed I have no experience with node.js builds but frankly I don't really mind what you use to build the project, as long as the result is jar file (something that all java developers know).
- The configuring/customizing is a must IMHO. The spring framework is designed to be easily extensible and so should be the actuator UI. Otherwise what happens is people extend the spring-boot actuators, add some new actuators, and then they can't extend the UI. A few more thoughts on this one - why not take out all CSS files in another jar called spring-boot-admin-theme-default and so if user wants to have their own theme, they simply include their own webjar, instead of the default theme jar.
- +1 for angular-translate. Looks like the way to go.
- The way I see the authentication thing is the following - 1) there must be a login screen 2) there must be a stub that returns always a hard-coded token. 3) The user can specify a property to change the URL of the stub and return real (expiring) tokens. Whether it will be implemented with Oauth or not is details.

We would not want to do this activity.  I understand Spring Boot application auto-registers when the applicationContext is started and ready and this does not happen for PCF Blue to PCF Green deployments.

Poonam.. Thank you so much for responding. Please find my answers in italics below.
Overall I didn't yet understand your exact problem so here are some questions:

I have implemented Spring boot Admin client & server in my project and its successfully registering-an-application on the Spring boot Admin UI.

Which version are you using? 
(Spring-boot-admin-server - version 1.5.1) (Spring-boot-admin-client - version 1.5.7)

Whenever application is deployed from PCF blue region to PCF green region it does not show the updates on the Spring boot Admin UI

Do you miss the new version information or do you miss entire services? In green region I miss seeing entire services
Do the instances from blue and green register at the same spring boot admin instance? We have Jenkins pipeline which first deploys in blue region and then to green region for any environment. When blue pipeline step is completed, it registers on admin server and it shows the new version and also number of instances correctly. When the pipeline moves from blue to green region, it stops the blue services (which is correct) but it does not show the green services at all. Then we end up restaging our applications in Green region just to get them registered in spring boot admin server application
Or do you use different admin servers for each region? Each region (dev/qa/prod) has its own Spring-boot-admin-server application deployed.

I understand Spring Boot application auto-registers when the applicationContext is started and ready and this does not happen for PCF Blue to PCF Green deployments.

In fact (if you use spring-boot-admin-client) the application uses a scheduled task and registers over and over again. Then why my client is not registering over and over again? What am I missing?. I did set the de.codecentric.boot.admin.client.registration.ApplicationRegistrator to Debug and I see everytime the instance routes from blue to green, it does keep registering with [registrationTask1] [de.codecentric.boot.admin.client.registration.ApplicationRegistrator] - Application refreshed itself as 4b287e58
I was trying the approach to invoke a rest service after each Blue/Green deployment which would invoke RegistrationApplicationListener.startRegisterTask(). Will this work? 
I cannot update Spring boot Admin to 2.X as it would require all my applications also to be upgraded to Spring boot 2.X. I also read (http://codecentric.github.io/spring-boot-admin/current/#monitoring-spring-boot-1.5.x) does it mean only Spring boot Admin should be upgraded to 2.X and Client can stay on 1.5.X?
. When the registering task is running, starting it has no effect. Did you cross check that the services are registering using the correct spring.boot.admin.url?
Both my Blue & Green instances should register to the same spring.boot.admin.url as the code package is same and its declared once only.
Futher more to this: When blue registers it shows Application refreshed itself as 232a8ac2 (my app instance id) - which is correct and it shows on my admin UI also.
Then when Blue -> Green deployment happens I see in logs Updated app with guid 6d685f0e-6041-424d-bb77-8f7ead050a9e ({"name"=>"billing-dev"}) and Application refreshed itself as 232a8ac2 (my app instance id).
This is correct, as the when blue -> green deployment happens, the same instance becomes green. So the instance id should remain same.
Looks like the problem is with my Admin server, its not showing the instance registered rather than shows it offline.  Which admin server logs can be enabled to see if Admin server is picking up or not?
I really appreciate your help on this.
Thanks,
Poonam.
. Yes, the name in Blue is billing-dev-candidate and the name in Green is billing-dev. (It removes -candidate from any application name from Blue->Green deployment)
When PCF deploys from Blue to Green, it updates the route and the name of the application. 
Instance remains same, it will not be restarted and there would be zero impact to live traffic.
Currently we are restaging each application after blue->green deployments, just for Spring-boot-Admin to show the green instances registered. Thats why I want to find out if its possible not to restage applications after blue->green deployment coz its like an add on chore for us.. The sba-client needs to be aware of the new name (by reconfiguring spring.boot.admin.client.instance.name). How can this be done? Is application restart/restage the only option?
Do you reconfigure the application at runtime? Yes we reconfigure application at runtime, updating the app route and name of the application.
Are you using the Spring Cloud's @RefreshScope? What should I do @RefreshScope?

oxygensar:
Sorry for late response. You're right. When configuring message text via application properties they first get resolved by Spring and only later by Spring Boot Admin when actually sending the message. Probably it's worth mentioning this explicitly in the docs. Thank you!

. @joshiste  : Thanks for the help !!
So, first , I separated SBA into its own server without mixing with the eureka server since it was giving me other errors,  then I updated it to Spring Cloud Camden.SR2 and 1.4.4 SBA. And on the client side I had to give these properties to make everything work. Although my management.context-path is no different than server.context-path, I had to explicitly mention the management context path along with the status and health check URLs to make it work.
eureka.instance.metadataMap.instanceId=${spring.application.name}:${spring.application.instance_id}
eureka.instance.metadataMap.management.context-path=${server.context-path}
eureka.instance.statusPageUrlPath: ${server.context-path}/info
eureka.instance.healthCheckUrlPath: ${server.context-path}/health
eureka.client.serviceUrl.defaultZone=http://localhost:8761/eureka/
eureka.client.registerWithEureka: true
eureka.client.fetchRegistry: true

. This is because the embedded Zuul proxy which proxies the /turbine.stream endpoint closes the stream after a short time.

. Yes, they show up, then stop when the stream closes from Zuul.
I don't think it seems Zuul can handle event streams very well, so imho it would probably be better to go against the turbine.stream directly.. > Any feedback on this? Otherwise I close the issue in 2 days...
Sorry, still on Christmas vacation here... :)
But I checked with 1.4.5, and everything seems to work fine now. So as far as I'm concerned, this issue can be closed.. > Above all done, I still have the topic error.

Question is

and use the /turbine.stream endpoint directly instead, since that works fine.

Turns out I spoke too soon above: the patched Zuul filter also cuts the stream after a short while.
I can't see another way to fix this than using @EnableTurbine / @EnableTurbineAmqp and modifying turbineCtrl.js in the spring-boot-admin-server-ui-turbine module and using a locally built version instead. I was meaning to send a PR about this, but lots of stuff got in the way, as stuff often does...
But with the changes above, stuff works for me.. > But with the changes above, stuff works for me.
...i.e. change this line in spring-boot-admin-server-ui-turbine/src/main/webpack/turbineCtrl.js: 
$scope.streamUrl = 'api/turbine/stream?cluster=' + $scope.selectedCluster;
to this:
$scope.streamUrl = 'turbine.stream?cluster=' + $scope.selectedCluster;
. Might your issue be related to this? https://github.com/codecentric/spring-boot-admin/issues/351#issuecomment-273288074
The embedded Zuul has issues with the Turbine stream, but the fix above makes the view work..

. Some for me. This is critical, because usually one would deploy the admin ui to a tomcat webserver, where the servlet path is derived from the application filename.
So if you deploy a my-admin.war file, the location will be http://yourserver:8080/my-admin.
If only run locally with embedded tomcat, this can be simulated with setting server.servlet.context-path=/my-admin. Note that any server.* settings only apply to embedded tomcat!
In this case, as others mentioned already, spring-admin will still try to resolve the assets from localhost:8080/assets/... even if server.servlet.context-path is set!. I can confirm the 2.1.0 client works with 2.0.4 server. thanks!. Sorry, but your link is for an embedded tomcat webserver ("78. Embedded Web Servers"). Therefor any  server.* properties affect the application only in embedded mode.
(or course I tried setting those properties anyway, but as expected that did not change anything).
But as said, I'm running the war file on a normal dedicated tomcat webserver! Therefore I set the reverse proxy configurations as stated above (eg X-Forwarded-Proto).
And also, it worked in all the previous versions. So I assume this is probably a bug due to some changes since spring-boot 2.1.x?. I could solve it adding the following to server.xml before AccessLogValve:
<Valve className="org.apache.catalina.valves.RemoteIpValve" remoteIpHeader="X-Forwarded-For"  protocolHeader="X-Forwarded-Proto" />. Of course my users will hit those stale connections as well.
Anyways, if spring-boot users rely on both the spring-hikari and the spring-sba configuration, they might be confused as me that the application shows offline, even though it is working fine in general.
Offline state is eg if the *.war application is undeployed in tomcat and thus physically removed. Then SBA usually shows the OFFLINE state. I think, as you suggested, that should be the only case when offline is to be shown. So TIMEOUT could be a nice improvement.. That's true indeed. Thanks for the discussion though!.

I'm working on an update of a Spring Boot Cookbook, where I've provided examples of how to integrate SBA, to SB 2.0, and would love to be able to test the integration and hopefully provide some feedback.. Looking at the code I'm not even seeing where this property is being consumed or bounded to a Properties object.... As we switched to k8s, we now use Spring Cloud Kubernetes discovery component, so it solved the problem by relying on k8s to only expose the actually running pods all the time.
We've also added a custom implementation of InstanceDiscoveryListener, which overrides discover method and does some cleanup of stale services:
protected void discover() {
        final Set<String> staleApplicationIds = getServices();
        for (String serviceId : discoveryClient.getServices()) {
                    for (ServiceInstance instance : discoveryClient.getInstances(serviceId)) {
                        Mono<InstanceId> applicationId = registerInstance(instance);
                        staleApplicationIds.remove(applicationId.block().getValue());
                    }
        }
        for (String staleApplicationId : staleApplicationIds) {
            LOGGER.info("Application ({}) missing in DiscoveryClient services ",
                    staleApplicationId);
            registry.deregister(InstanceId.of(staleApplicationId));
        }
    }. Oh, nice, looks like it was added in 2.0.  We were migrating from 1.5 line, which didn’t have this feature.. {

That would be a solution, given that the rest of my applications were using the sale clustering solution.
However the company I work at prefers to run different instances without clustering and letting the load balancer distribute the load over the instances. That's why this solution is not suited for the admin-server and so I prefer chattiness over single point of failure.

mikexliu:
I couldn't think of a case where we would only want to register against exactly one admin-server if there are multiple available. My use case is we have a centralized admin-server but each service also is hosting its own admin-server. I would like to have the data be pushed to both endpoints.
If the centralized admin-server goes down, it's still accessible via the service itself (or if you have multiple dedicated admin-servers, then they would have the data immediately as opposed to having to wait for the next registration).

http://cloud.spring.io/spring-cloud-static/Brixton.SR5/#_eureka_s_health_checks
Using Eureka on Cloudfoundry
Cloudfoundry has a global router so that all instances of the same app have
the same hostname (it’s the same in other PaaS solutions with a similar
architecture). This isn’t necessarily a barrier to using Eureka, but if you
use the router (recommended, or even mandatory depending on the way your
platform was set up), you need to explicitly set the hostname and port
numbers (secure or non-secure) so that they use the router. You might also
want to use instance metadata so you can distinguish between the instances
on the client (e.g. in a custom load balancer). By default, the
eureka.instance.instanceId is vcap.application.instance_id. For example:
application.yml
eureka:
  instance:
    hostname: ${vcap.application.uris[0]}
    nonSecurePort: 80

. It's clearly stating that it can't allocate direct memory buffers: OutOfDirectMemoryError: failed to allocate 256 byte(s) of direct memory (used: 10485655, max: 10485760)] with root cause
IIRC the Pivotal Java Buildpacks now explicitely limit all native memory "pools" if possible. What you are looking for is -XX:MaxDirectMemorySize set in the JAVA_OPTS. (Perhaps indirectly from the Buildpack.) You'd might wan't to increase that. But you should monitor this closely (e.g. with Micrometer) in case this is allocating more and more direct memory buffers then re-using. The Hotspot JVM also has a habbit of caching once allocated buffers for re-use. Tunable with -Djdk.nio.maxCachedBufferSize if I remeber correctly.. @joshiste No, direct memory buffer allocation is not part of the heap managed (in the sense of garbage collected) pools (Eden, Old, Metaspace, Compressed Class Space, ...). It's memory directly allocated by the JVM from the host OS. In a sense it's still managed due to being limitable by -XX:MaxDirectMemorySize and pools are reused (-Djdk.nio.MaxCachedBufferSize) for the JVM not having to re-allocate memory.
I'd have assumed this is a application specific thing and unrelated to SBA. One should monitor the metrics and see if its a steady growth or actually triggered by some specific action within the application. E.g. monitoring the direct memory buffer metrics with and without SBA polling for information on the application itself. Perhaps some queried actutor endpoints are causing steady direct buffer allocations in this netty setup..

. I found the bug it is due to a bug on karma-phantomjs-launcher/index.js. It doesn't work well with mac sierra and try to evaluate the path like if it believes to be on a windows so it crashs on a null path
I find a workaround witch is not very clean as it works only for mac  users ... I removed the line for windows :-) `
at the end of this file you can find 
```
PhantomJSBrowser.prototype = {
  name: 'PhantomJS',
DEFAULT_CMD: {
    linux: require('phantomjs-prebuilt').path,
    darwin: require('phantomjs-prebuilt').path,
    win32: phantomJSExePath()
  },
  ENV_CMD: 'PHANTOMJS_BIN'
}
```
replace it by 
```
PhantomJSBrowser.prototype = {
  name: 'PhantomJS',
DEFAULT_CMD: {
    linux: require('phantomjs-prebuilt').path,
    darwin: require('phantomjs-prebuilt').path
  },
  ENV_CMD: 'PHANTOMJS_BIN'
}
```

jakobjoachim:
I'm having a similar issue, we are hosting our spring applications in containers but are not in charge of the "gateway service" that uses SSL to communicate to the world. As such we have no good way of managing SSL certificates required for using SBA with https. All our other applications communicate with each other over HTTP and we would have hoped to do the same with SBA. Is there any way to get SBA to act like its using https in the hrefs we have configured via "admin.ui.public-url".. I was facing a similar problem, i solved it by setting the spring.boot.admin.ui.public-url property.
For example if Zuul is localhost:80/admin and the spring boot admin server is localhost:8080 setting spring.boot.admin.ui.public-url: http://localhost:80/admin/ will change the href in <base> to localhost:80/admin. Note that its not compatible with the adminContextPath property. It seems to override the public-url property.

addozhang:
We are using 1.5.7 SBA which adds a TurbineRouteLocator to proxy api/turbine/clusters request to turbine.stream via zuul. But as we know zuul 1.x not supporting SSE and turbine.stream is just a SSE one. Zuul's SimpleHostRoutingFilter holds a connection pool and maxPerRouteConnections defaults to 20. Zuul never releases the connection to turbine.stream.
So we try to add one option for SBA to use turbine.stream directly and SBA will perceive client (such as brower) closing connection. .
beanball: That worked but I also had to change the port the web server was running on in the container to the same value as the external mapping. That seems a little burdensome, but I have enough control over our projects that I can do that..

On Wed, Dec 21, 2016 at 12:43 AM Johannes Edmeier notifications@github.com
wrote:

When the service-/health-/managment-url are not configured explicit,
they're "guessed" for fat-jar boot applications based on
InetAdress.getLocalHost() / server.adress / server.port /
server.context-path.
This is described in the Docs
http://codecentric.github.io/spring-boot-admin/1.4.4/#spring-boot-admin-client
and is done by the ApplicationFactory
https://github.com/codecentric/spring-boot-admin/blob/master/spring-boot-admin-starter-client/src/main/java/de/codecentric/boot/admin/client/registration/DefaultApplicationFactory.java#L55
.
And also it's intended behaviour.
At first I thought that you said the health- and management-url are
guessed even though you specified them explicitly. If this is not the case
then everything works as expected.

eureka:

        fetchRegistry: true

        homePageUrl: https://${eureka.instance.hostname}:${server.port}/
        securePort: ${server.port}

I come to realize yesterday that some properties does not have any effect being on metadata. 
Yes, If possible I want to set spring.boot.admin.client.server-base-url because CF requires a specific baseUrl to access to the specific CF instance. 
Also, spring.boot.admin.auto-deregistration would better be registered as true because CF is not a permanent environment. Instance can be created and destroyed and would result in showing down status for some of the instances. 
I can also set the above 2 properties in each application as well but then spring-boot-admin would not work out of the box. Maybe, let that be and write in the documentation that the 2 properties should be set in each application. . Sorry for taking a long time. 
I finally managed to set the 4 properties automatically in spring-boot-admin-client and confirmed that all of them is working.
4 properties.
https://github.com/tetsushiawano/spring-boot-admin-client-app/blob/master/src/main/resources/application.yml#L6-L9
Below is the demo url.
http://spring-boot-admin.cfapps.io/#/applications
Below is the modified branch.
https://github.com/codecentric/spring-boot-admin/compare/master...tetsushiawano:feature/support_cf_v2?expand=1

```
@lombok.Data
@ConfigurationProperties(prefix = "spring.boot.admin.client.instance")
public class CloudFoundryInstanceProperties extends InstanceProperties {
    /*
     * Base url for computing the service-url to register with. The path is inferred at runtime, and appended to the base url.
     /
    private String serviceBaseUrl;
@Override
@Value("${vcap.application.uris[0]:}")
public void setServiceBaseUrl(String serviceBaseUrl) {
    if (!StringUtils.isEmpty(serviceBaseUrl)) {
        this.serviceBaseUrl = "http://" + serviceBaseUrl;
    }
}

}
``

ctoestreich:
Perhaps the metrics should be a sorted set instead of a List. @joshiste Adding all metrics would be easier.  I think the code to filter gauge and counters is already overkill just to accommodate different gauges.  I don't know what the intent of rich gauges was (as I don't see anything "rich" in my UIs), but if we made all metrics just simple bars it would at least cover the use case that we need.  My change has the advantage of allowing clients to dictate which metrics they want to see in the admin.  We have other services that consume all of these metrics and I we emit hundreds of metrics per service.  Rendering a contextual subset is probably suitable to our case, but showing all metrics would encapsulate this as well.  
Your comment has two different suggestions of work.  Show all metrics OR change custom metric set to metadata property.  I am happy to augment to fit one of those, but lets decide which one first and then I will make the change.. Okay i will clean this up and do all metrics grouped by the prefix.  Are we okay to simplify the gauges or do you want to keep those regex tests around and the "rich gauge" feature?  What exactly are the rich gauges supposed to be?. I went back to this recently and there are a few issues with adding "all metrics".
First issue is that grouping and ordering of the metrics requires iterating the metrics more than once and the best grouping that can be implied is just grabbing the first word before the first period.  So that custom metrics like "web.access.controller.action.count", "web.access.rate" and "web.errors.count" would all get grouped together.  This isn't inherently a "problem" it just makes the page render slower due to having to "prebucket" and sort and buckets some different metrics together.  This can also throw off what the "max" value for a set is given that you now could be mixing jvm.memory and jvm.threads together for example.  
The other major issue is how to deal with timers by using the gauge style display.  For example we have the following metrics:
"web.access.controller.IndexController.action.index.fifteenMinuteRate": 0.0043852199194119295,
"web.access.controller.IndexController.action.index.oneMinuteRate": 0.03198334378909226
This doesn't quite fit into the gauge/bar graph that is currently used.
I am open to thoughts on this.
. @joshiste After spending a few hours working on this the simplicity of just specifying the interested metrics was pretty nice from a coding and display perspective.  To just boot a microservice below are the number of metrics that are created.  After it gets running there are may more given all the http interceptor, amqp and other custom metrics that start getting counted.  Not to mention our primary monolith has about 2k controller/action that log access rates, counts etc.
So for me to say show: "jvm.memory, web.access, threads" limits this scope to the SBA screen to stuff we want to see at a glance which the bulk of these are emitted to our metrics aggregation platform.

evernat:
@joshiste 

So will you rework the code for 2.x?

Do you mean rework the PR (as a new PR certainly) to work with spring-boot-admin 2.0.0-SNAPSHOT?
If yes, can you help us by saying what files in the PR are not good anymore and if possible how those files should be changed? And is there an example similar to this PR or should the (new) PR be the new example of such integration?. @joshiste I agree for the module in version 2.0.0 as an external module, if the module is migrated one day.
But @dvtoever is the main concerned by this PR and maybe also by the module migration and by #683 whatever it means, so I suggest to have his voice on this PR.. Instead of javamelody-core dependency and of javaMelody FilterRegistrationBean (which is not enough anyway), I suggest to show an example to add javamelody-spring-boot-starter in pom.xml. For example:
xml
<!-- https://github.com/javamelody/javamelody/wiki/SpringBootStarter -->
<dependency>
    <groupId>net.bull.javamelody</groupId>
    <artifactId>javamelody-spring-boot-starter</artifactId>
    <version>${javamelody.version}</version>
</dependency>. ehcache dependency is not needed here anymore: it can be removed.
And I suggest to add the iText 2.1.7 dependency (licence MPL or LGPL at your choice) and the Log4J dependency, in order to have PDF links in reports (I think PDF links are important in the reports) and to have some logs:
xml
        <dependency>
            <groupId>com.lowagie</groupId>
            <artifactId>itext</artifactId>
            <version>2.1.7</version>
            <exclusions>
                <exclusion>
                    <groupId>bouncycastle</groupId>
                    <artifactId>bcmail-jdk14</artifactId>
                </exclusion>
                <exclusion>
                    <groupId>bouncycastle</groupId>
                    <artifactId>bcprov-jdk14</artifactId>
                </exclusion>
                <exclusion>
                    <artifactId>bctsp-jdk14</artifactId>
                    <groupId>bouncycastle</groupId>
                </exclusion>
            </exclusions>
        </dependency>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>log4j</groupId>
            <artifactId>log4j</artifactId>
            <version>1.2.17</version>
</dependency>
You could also copy the collector server log4j.xml file in resources of this module.
And XStream 1.4.10 dependency and aws-java-sdk-cloudwatch dependency could possibly be added to be able to export data as JSON or XML and to export data to AWS CloudWatch, but they are less important and I suppose that they could be added by the "admin" user.. This filterRegistrationBean() is not needed to make the collector server work and it should be removed I suppose. (There is a CollectorServlet below.)
Or if what you want is to monitor the spring-boot-admin server itself, then it is not enough (javamelody-spring-boot-starter may be better for this).. Parameters.addCollectorApplication(applicationName, Parameters.parseUrl(application.getServiceUrl())); to be replaced by CollectorServlet.addCollectorApplication(applicationName, application.getServiceUrl())
(using the latest javamelody-core snapshot). to be replaced by CollectorServlet.removeCollectorApplication(applicationName);. <javamelody.version>1.69.0</javamelody.version> can now be used to use the new methods in CollectorServlet. The FilterRegistrationBean is not enough because in general a SessionListener is also installed. See https://github.com/javamelody/javamelody/blob/master/javamelody-spring-boot-starter/src/main/java/net/bull/javamelody/JavaMelodyAutoConfiguration.java#L87
Then the spring-boot-starter also adds monitoring of RestControllers, RestTemplates, Services, spring context and more.
So adding the javamelody-spring-boot-starter to monitor the spring-boot-admin server should be much simpler than adding filter, sessionlistener, etc.. No, I think that many users would be really happy to have the pdf reports. And, adding a iText dependency would be debatable in a monitored app but this dependency (with exclusions on transitive dependencies) is in my opinion not a problem in spring-boot-admin. So I think that we should really keep the iText dependency like it is now.
For Log4J, it is not included at the moment and finally it seems not needed since there is already a log4j-over-slf4j dependency in spring-boot-admin..

"registrationTask1" #111 prio=5 os_prio=31 tid=0x00007fb20244f000 nid=0xfd03 runnable [0x00007000143e1000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
    at java.net.Inet6AddressImpl.lookupAllHostAddr(Native Method)
    at java.net.InetAddress$2.lookupAllHostAddr(InetAddress.java:928)
    at java.net.InetAddress.getAddressesFromNameService(InetAddress.java:1323)
    at java.net.InetAddress.getLocalHost(InetAddress.java:1500)
    - locked <0x00000006c00784b0> (a java.lang.Object)
    at de.codecentric.boot.admin.client.registration.DefaultApplicationFactory.getLocalHost(DefaultApplicationFactory.java:119)
    at de.codecentric.boot.admin.client.registration.DefaultApplicationFactory.getServiceHost(DefaultApplicationFactory.java:104)
    at de.codecentric.boot.admin.client.registration.DefaultApplicationFactory.getServiceUrl(DefaultApplicationFactory.java:65)
    at de.codecentric.boot.admin.client.registration.DefaultApplicationFactory.getManagementUrl(DefaultApplicationFactory.java:77)
    at de.codecentric.boot.admin.client.registration.DefaultApplicationFactory.createApplication(DefaultApplicationFactory.java:46)
    at de.codecentric.boot.admin.client.registration.ApplicationRegistrator.createApplication(ApplicationRegistrator.java:126)
    at de.codecentric.boot.admin.client.registration.ApplicationRegistrator.register(ApplicationRegistrator.java:65)
    at de.codecentric.boot.admin.client.registration.RegistrationApplicationListener$1.run(RegistrationApplicationListener.java:80)
    at org.springframework.scheduling.support.DelegatingErrorHandlingRunnable.run(DelegatingErrorHandlingRunnable.java:54)
    at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:511)
    at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.runAndReset(FutureTask.java:308)
    at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.access$301(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:180)
    at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.run(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:294)
    at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)
    at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
    at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748). Ok. I fix it according to this: https://stackoverflow.com/a/34646639/2811722.
Just adding the Spring thread pool task scheduler bean manually with a bigger pool size fixes it.
@Bean
    public ThreadPoolTaskScheduler taskScheduler(){
        ThreadPoolTaskScheduler taskScheduler = new ThreadPoolTaskScheduler();
        taskScheduler.setPoolSize(20);
        return  taskScheduler;
    }. I agree. This wasn't an issue of SBA client just lack of knowledge of Spring Scheduling from my side.
Thanks for the feedback!.

dimazig:
My browser is Chrome 62 and new Date().toISOString() returns something like "2017-12-11T00:56:20.106Z"
My timezone is AEDT which is Sydney, Australia
new Date() produces something like "Mon Dec 11 2017 12:00:01 GMT+1100 (AUS Eastern Daylight Time)". I debugged and found the problem. + symbol replaced with a space by tomcat. Tomcat version is 8.5.23.
Class org.apache.tomcat.util.buf.UDecoder
Line: 107 
if( buff[ j ] == '+' && query) {
                buff[idx]= (byte)' ' ;
So either this is a bug in Tomcat or better to send DateTime in a different format like UNIX Time UTC. That quite strange cause a browser requests http://localhost:8080/admin/api/applications/bef38cd6/auditevents?after=2017-12-13T02:13:00%2B0000
so + is encoded as %2B but Tomcat tries to decode it twice. Trying to find where is the first trasnformation from %2B to +. There is definitely some s..t happening in Tomcat. http://tomcat.10.x6.nabble.com/character-is-always-encoded-in-url-path-after-request-dispatch-since-59317-td5062787.html
I would change the format of DateTime to something more reliable than ISO. https://developer.ibm.com/answers/questions/249153/urls-with-or-2b-in-the-path-or-2b-in-the-query-are.html. Or at least you could convert DateTime to UTCin JavaScript before sending so it would end up with Z rather than +OFFSET. I've found what's causing the issue. This issue caused by ZuulFilter
I need to add zuul.forceOriginalQueryStringEncoding=true to fix it and disable double encoding.

Dellaire:
I had this issue too, in my case, my server had the following dependencies:
<dependency>
    <groupId>de.codecentric</groupId>
    <artifactId>spring-boot-admin-server</artifactId>
    <version>1.5.7</version>
</dependency>
<dependency>
    <groupId>de.codecentric</groupId>
    <artifactId>spring-boot-admin-server-ui</artifactId>
    <version>1.5.7</version>
</dependency>
The problematic class resides within servo-core-0.7.2.jar. I fixed this by manually increasing the version of the related dependency within my server:
<dependency>
    <groupId>com.netflix.servo</groupId>
    <artifactId>servo-core</artifactId>
    <version>0.12.20</version>
</dependency>.

snicoll:
Isn't that (according to @snicoll) to be avoided?

Correct.
The main issue I have here is that the BOM isn't used by the build at all, so I am with @joshiste there. Perhaps there is no need for such a change. In Spring Boot, we  do things a little bit differently.
The root pom is just used for the reactor, all modules inherit from spring-boot-build which itself inherits from spring-boot-dependencies so rather than moving the code you could move your "main" pom as sba-build (for instance), inherit  from  sba-dependencies, and have your modules inherit from sba-build. That way, you actually use the dependencyManagement section of the bom.
Let me know if you have any question.. A bom shouldn't have a dependencies section. Also, ideally the project should use said BOM internally rather than having it as a side artifact. spring-boot-admin  brings full dependency management for a particular version of Spring Boot. This BOM should only provide dependency management for the modules that this project handles (as you've indicated in the content  below).. We use explicit versions in a bom usually.. I am not sure all that is needed. Probably worth adding plugin management only for the things this project actually uses..
