``` java
package com.ownapp;
import java.time.Duration;
import java.time.Instant;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;
import java.util.logging.Level;
import org.reactivestreams.Publisher;
import org.slf4j.Logger;
import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;
import de.codecentric.boot.admin.server.domain.events.InstanceEndpointsDetectedEvent;
import de.codecentric.boot.admin.server.domain.events.InstanceEvent;
import de.codecentric.boot.admin.server.domain.events.InstanceRegistrationUpdatedEvent;
import de.codecentric.boot.admin.server.domain.events.InstanceStatusChangedEvent;
import de.codecentric.boot.admin.server.domain.values.InstanceId;
import de.codecentric.boot.admin.server.services.InfoUpdateTrigger;
import de.codecentric.boot.admin.server.services.InfoUpdater;
import reactor.core.Disposable;
import reactor.core.publisher.Flux;
import reactor.core.publisher.Mono;
import reactor.core.scheduler.Schedulers;
import reactor.retry.Retry;
public class OwnInfoUpdateTrigger extends InfoUpdateTrigger {
    private Duration updateInterval = Duration.ofSeconds(10);
    private Duration statusLifetime = Duration.ofSeconds(20);
    private static final Logger log = LoggerFactory.getLogger(OwnInfoUpdateTrigger.class);
    private Disposable intervalSubscription;
    private Map lastQueried = new HashMap<>();
    private InfoUpdater infoUpdater;
public OwnInfoUpdateTrigger(final InfoUpdater infoUpdater, final Publisher<InstanceEvent> publisher) {
    super(infoUpdater, publisher);
    this.infoUpdater = infoUpdater;
}

@Override
public void start() {
    super.start();
    intervalSubscription = Flux.interval(updateInterval)
            .doOnSubscribe(subscription -> log.debug("Scheduled info update every {}", updateInterval))
            .log(log.getName(), Level.FINEST)
            .subscribeOn(Schedulers.newSingle("info-monitor"))
            .flatMap((i) -> this.updateInfoForAllInstances())
            .retryWhen(Retry.any()
                    .retryMax(Integer.MAX_VALUE)
                    .doOnRetry(ctx -> log.error("Resubscribing after uncaught error", ctx.exception())))
            .subscribe();
    log.debug("Started!");
}

@Override
public void stop() {
    super.stop();
    if (intervalSubscription != null) {
        intervalSubscription.dispose();
    }
}

@Override
protected Publisher<?> handle(Flux<InstanceEvent> publisher) {
    log.debug("handling publisher");
    return publisher.subscribeOn(Schedulers.newSingle("info-updater"))
            .filter(event -> event instanceof InstanceEndpointsDetectedEvent
                    || event instanceof InstanceStatusChangedEvent
                    || event instanceof InstanceRegistrationUpdatedEvent)
            .flatMap(this::updateInfo);
}

protected Mono<Void> updateInfo(InstanceEvent event) {
    return updateInfo(event.getInstance());
}

Mono<Void> updateInfoForAllInstances() {
    log.debug("Updating info for all instances");
    Instant expiryInstant = Instant.now()
            .minus(statusLifetime);
    return Flux.fromIterable(lastQueried.entrySet())
            .filter(e -> e.getValue()
                    .isBefore(expiryInstant))
            .map(Map.Entry::getKey)
            .flatMap(this::updateInfo)
            .then();
}

Mono<Void> updateInfo(InstanceId instanceId) {
    log.debug("Updating info for instance");
    return infoUpdater.updateInfo(instanceId)
            .doFinally(s -> lastQueried.put(instanceId, Instant.now()));
}

}
```

Stephan202:
@joshiste SNAPSHOTs don't represent stable versions. Jitpack allows one to reference arbitrary commits, branches and tags. This allows one to incorporate bug fixes right after they are merged, while keeping one's build reproducible.. I'm not claiming that software built off an arbitrary commit is stable; that's a concern orthogonal to whether the build itself is reproducible. Using JitPack gives one the latter without making any claims about the former. It fills a sweet spot between releases and SNAPSHOTs, in that releases provide both, while SNAPSHOTs provide neither.. Alright, too bad :).
In that case I'll paste the jitpack.yml file here verbatim for posterity, because we do plan to drop our fork following the next Spring Boot Admin release. So, future Googler, here it is:
yml
before_install:
  # Install the latest versions of Node.js and npm. This prevents
  # `CERT_UNTRUSTED` errors that happen when using the ancient versions
  # JitPack provides by default.
  - curl -f -o - https://raw.githubusercontent.com/creationix/nvm/v0.33.11/install.sh | bash
  - . "${HOME}/.nvm/nvm.sh"
  - nvm install --latest-npm
  # Make sure `groupdId`s inside `dependencyManagement` sections are also
  # updated. Drop this once https://github.com/jitpack/jitpack.io/issues/2886
  # is resolved.
  - find . -name pom.xml | xargs sed -i "s,\(<groupId>\)de.codecentric\(</groupId>\),\1${GROUP}.${ARTIFACT}\2,g"
install:
  - ./mvnw -B clean install -DskipTests -Drevision="${GIT_COMMIT}".

An example config would be:
spring.boot.admin.context-path=/sba-admin
spring.cloud.config.server.prefix=/config.

asibross:
Metadata may include entries that are not necessarily tags.
We need a way to distinguish between metadata entries that are tags and other entries, I see two options for this:
1. Key convention, i.e. tag:environment -> test 
2. A property that a consumer can set to define the tag keys, i.e. 
spring.boot.admin.metatdata-tags=environment,region
. Metadata is a flat string -> string map so what actually would be added is tags.environment -> test.
That makes sense to me and it also fits well with Eureka or any other form of registering apps.
I sent a PR that set the tags based on keys in the metadata that have the "tags." prefix.

    @Override

        webClient = webClient.mutate().clientConnector(connector).build();
    }

lucwillems:
https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current-SNAPSHOT/actuator-api/html/#overview-timestamps
seems all timestamp must be in ISO 8601 format.
. seems reasonable. i'm currently in the progress of moving ALL my none spring services into the consul service catalog using containerPilot. it allows to set  tags/metadata so SBA can do the checks.
only thing is that for example , mysql, will not have a HTTP based health check. the health is checked by containerPilot , which updates the  consul status based on the result of this periodic health check.
in this case SBA should not perform a HTTP based health check. so if no we have a a metadata flag like
sba.health.disable=true , we could skip this ?
. @joshiste the health check is done by containerPilot which will manage the service entry in consul.
it uses consul TTL for the service check , so if check fails to update the service entry before TTL expires , consul will mark the service as "bad" removed it after TTL.
if SBA can't do the health check it should rely/expect that external tools manage the status.

Imho the solution proposed in #804 would be a much better fit for this problem.

I can update my solution... actually - adding a new property under spring-admin namespace was my first idea, but I've chosen such way because it described In spring-boot-client documentation: http://codecentric.github.io/spring-boot-admin/2.0.3/#spring-boot-admin-client (see spring.boot.admin.client.instance.service-url property description).
Guessed based on service-base-url and server.context-path.
So, I made my solution to meet the documentation. 
Let's discuss the best way and Ill implement it. 
I suggest: 
1. add the new property (from #804) -spring.boot.admin.client.instance.service-pathin y solution change using of theserver.servlet.context-pathto this new one (so - both reactive and servlet branches will have the same implementation)
2. as  a default value for this new property - use the standardserver.servlet.context-path` - we'll save "as-is" the behavior for the non-reactive branch, and we'll provide the ability to configure it for the reactive branch as well.
What do you think?

masbaehr:
I found out the reason.. There were 2 problems
1st: I had to import the Let's encrypt X3 DER certificate to the java keystore. 
Then however the next problem seems to be related with HTTP2. If i turn on HTTP2 support it will still fail. With HTTP1.1 "server.http2.enabled=false"  on the CLIENT application. It will run.
Probaly this can be improved by using a different way to communicate. I've tested this in a plain java app and it works fine
```java
HttpClient client = HttpClient.newHttpClient();
    HttpRequest request = HttpRequest.newBuilder()
          .uri(URI.create("https://serverwithhttp2enabled:9480/actuator"))
          .build();
    client.sendAsync(request, BodyHandlers.ofString())
          .thenApply(HttpResponse::body)
          .thenAccept(System.out::println)
          .join();

```
Some other interesting fact.
Client-App:
Tomcat9 + http2 = Above Error
Undertow + http2 = OK. I'm closing this since the error is probably not caused by spring-boot-admin, but it seems to be an incompatibility while connecting with netty to tomcat9+h2 as protocol.
Now i've switched client and server to Undertow and it is working fine even with http2.
dzonekl:
I investigated further and stumbled upon the K8sCatalogWatcher, which is disabled by default. 
So this is also the bug you referred to. It is unfortunately not documented, so going through the code, I figured it out: 
So enabling the catalog watcher, and also enabling scheduling solved the issue: 


SpringBootApplication add: 
@EnableScheduling


In properties (yaml) add: 
spring:
  cloud:
    kubernetes:
        catalog-services-watch:
          enabled: true
          catalogServicesWatchDelay: 10000  (Default is 30 secs).
Now spring boot admin, will get a heartbeat. 
.

I am going to try it out and find the bug - meanwhile can we reopen the issue?. Hi @joshiste,
I was able to debug the JS code from within chrome and the JSON and all data seems to be fine. I set a break point before the "for"-loop and was able to run through the first two chartData iterations where the buckets are pushed. When I release the break point the issue with the out-of-memory crash is occurring.
So my assumption is that this is simply an issue of too many traces for a specific time period which are causing an out-of-memory exception. I guess the markup is growing to much. (The one within the template)
My suggestion would be to introduce a limit for those traces which is configurable and use
javascript
traces = myarray.slice(0,<limit>);
to shrink down the array if it hits that limit.
Also I would suggest to not show all traces for the time period of viewing but recalculate the time period according to the amount of traces returned by the slice call.
This way the shown time would not increase infinite, but move based on the traces.
Here is a screenshot of my first successful run through:

michformanek:
Hi, sorry. Yes. problem solved :) It was sort of stupid issue, because I changed extension-resource-locations as stated in docs, so that extension was registered, but did not configure spring boot app to allow static resources from that folder.  I just did ResourceHandlerRegistry.addResourceLocations and problem solved.
I found two more things that would be nice:
Allow Vue DevTools -> they are disabled, because main Spring Boot Admin bundle was build with production profile, and one has to allow them before first Vue is mounted.
Some way to import from Spring Boot Admin UI in my javascript - services and utils. But I think there should be some way to accomplish this through webpack configuration?.

src-r-r: Ah, I had assumed package-lock.json was something to protect concurrent execution (like a pid file). Just learned what it really is.. Right; sorry for the confusion. My build error occurred in a component using the library but it was my missing liblombok that was the issue.. I think only if you're using Eclipse. Even then Eclipse seemed to struggle finding the right libraries.. True; I didn't need to do this, but requirements are useful as a reminder.. Probably self-explanatory if you work on Java a lot of the time. IMHO, build docs should take the premise of "if you're new to 90% of what's used in this project, this will get you going." Docs like these take up only a little space, but can save someone a lot of work..
